data.text: Light Blanket for Summer Bikepacking
What do you recommend in lightweight blankets for summer bikepacking?
Quilts! I have 1 that compresses down to a 12oz can size and weight 1 lb

data.text: Big fan of my Sierra Designs Nitro 35 quilt

data.text: Shouldn't need blankets as they are heavy and bulky unless meaning sleeping quilt.. quilts are great as they are far more efficient, light and pack small with the added benefit of being adjustable.

data.text: Decathlon
data.author: Dirk Meier

data.text: I have the 20F version of the Sierra Designs Nitro quilt and love it. For much warmer weather I have an older 40F REI bag I picked up at a garage sale. It zips out flat like a blanket or as a roomy mummy bag. Often I use it like a quilt and just zip the foot box area. Most places I bikepack are pretty chilly at night so the Nitro works well for me. With the quilts, you have as many ways to vent heat as with a blanket so they can cover a wide temp range.
data.author: Wade Patterson

data.text: I use a super thin down bag (designed for adventure racing) - still good protection (as you cannot here perfectly predict the weather over a multinight trip), but minimum bulk and weight.
data.author: Juha Virtanen

data.text: It depends on where you're planning on riding, for example the nights in Colorado high country can be pretty chilly even during the summer. I prefer a super lightweight down quilt on most of my late spring through fall trips.
data.author: Petr Ineman

data.text: I have the Rumpl one and I love it!
data.author: Jonathan Allen

data.text: My summer quilt is a Big Agnes Canyon. It is rainy and humid during the spring/summer where I am, so I went synthetic instead of down, but it is light and packs small.
data.author: Bradley Craig

data.text: A sleeping bag liner. Easy to kick off if too warm.
